input_text.Prompt:
Click Here to Read More

According to a Progressive Insurance study, around one-third of drivers are confident in their own ability to text and drive – even though the majority believe that distracted driving is the biggest cause of vehicle accidents and more than 90 percent said it should be illegal.

The starkest difference in attitudes is between younger and older drivers. More than 60 percent of 18- to 34-year-olds said they're confident in their ability to safely text while driving, compared to fewer than 6 percent of individuals 55 and older.

In 2015 alone, 3,477 people were killed and 391,000 were injured in motor vehicle crashes involving distracted drivers, according to data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Teens were the largest age group reported as distracted at the time of fatal crashes.

Generate a summary:
input_text.Response A: Many people think they can text and drive at the same time, but a lot of people have accidents because they are distracted. This is especially true for teenagers. More than 3,000 people were killed in accidents caused by distracted drivers in 2015 alone.
input_text.Response B: According to a study, around one-third of drivers are confident in their ability to text and drive, even though the majority believe that distracted driving is the biggest cause of vehicle accidents. The study also found that younger drivers are more likely to believe they can safely text while driving, compared to older individuals. In 2015 alone, 3,477 people were killed and 391,000 were injured in motor vehicle crashes involving distracted drivers.

input_meta.preamble_a: Respond using only short words and simple language, as if you were talking to a child.
input_meta.preamble_b: Respond in a cautious, defensive and uncertain way, as if you are unfamilar with the topic.
